nit: I'm personally never a fan of "set -e". I generally prefer to add error checking where I need it, with error messages. The -e can lead to some silent failures.
why have the "|| exit 1" if you're going to use "set -e"?
These are prime examples where error checking with a clean error message is desirable.

replaced stat with ": <$BOOTIMAGE_ISO". The idea is to execute some command that would fail and print out ERRNO if the file can't be opened. I replaced stat with the redirection trick because that opens the file for reading (and closes immediately), which is a better test. ":" is a built-in null statement in Bourne shell that does nothing and always succeeds.
Can this be generalized to come from a config file so that we could add an option for a different config file with different settings? For libvirt for example?

This still isn't right. It is converting to a string to be formatted into a string. So end result is the same, just with some extra work being done that is not necessary.

The actually issue reported in the bug appears to be that the exception raised here is the problem. You are instantiating exc_class with a string and a tuple. What you actually want to do is format a string that gets set as the message.

So "(msg, ..." needs to be changed to "(msg % ..." to fix that.

Hi,

The status of the Neutron devstack plugin(s) is a bit sad, basically the only plugin that works is the legacy one and in the last PTG it was decided to un-deprecate it and delete the "new" (it's from 2016) one. Here's a note about it from the last PTG summary email [0]:

<snippet>
## Future of lib/neutron and lib/neutron-legacy in devstack

In Devstack there are currently 2 modules which can configure Neutron. Old
one called "lib/neutron-legacy" and the new one called "lib/neutron". It is
like that since many cycles that "lib/neutron-legacy" is deprecated. But it is
still used everywhwere. New module isn't still finished and isn't working fine.
This is very confusing for users as really maintained and recommended is still
"lib/neutron-legacy" module.

During the discussion Sean Collins explained us that originally this new
module was created as an attempt to refactor old module, and to make Neutron in
the Devstack better to maintain. But now we see that this process failed as new
module isn't still used and we don't have any cycles to work on it. So our
final conclusion is to "undeprecate" old "lib/neutron-legacy" and get rid of
the new module.
</snippet>

[0] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-June/015368.html

/COMMIT_MSG.message: If
a port from vlan type network
Can you explain more about this? And how this patch helps?

I will add some more explanation on the bug launchpad :)
https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1824504

reproduce step:
env:
We enabled l2population in mechanism driver, and enable l2_population, arp_responder on agent side.

/etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini
[ml2]
type_drivers = vxlan,vlan,flat,local
tenant_network_types = vlan
mechanism_drivers =openvswitch,l2population

/etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/openvswitch_agent.ini
[agent]
l2_population = True
arp_responder = True

1. Create a vlan network.
2. Create 3 VMs(vm1, vm2, vm3) in different compute nodes(host1, host2, host3) with the vlan network.
3. Modify vm1's ip address, for example the new ip address is 192.168.111.95.
4. Login to host2 and host3, you will find the vm1's ip address arp related openflows in br-tun.
# ovs-ofctl dump-flows br-tun | grep ARP | grep 192.168.111.95
 cookie=0x9b7c0a4c49fcb20b, duration=12.806s, table=21, n_packets=0, n_bytes=0, idle_age=12, priority=1,arp,dl_vlan=3,arp_tpa=192.168.111.95 actions=move:NXM_OF_ETH_SRC[]->NXM_OF_ETH_DST[],mod_dl_src:fa:16:3e:ad:40:47,load:0x2->NXM_OF_ARP_OP[],move:NXM_NX_ARP_SHA[]->NXM_NX_ARP_THA[],move:NXM_OF_ARP_SPA[]->NXM_OF_ARP_TPA[],load:0xfa163ead4047->NXM_NX_ARP_SHA[],load:0xc0a86f5f->NXM_OF_ARP_SPA[],IN_PORT

Then when we ping 192.168.111.95 from a VM or namespace, the first arp mac destination is ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff, all the compute nodes will receive this packet, and because of arp responder for 192.168.111.95, 2 or more computed nodes will reply this packet, this will make the mac looks like exist on several compute nodes, this is impossible on common situation, and it will confuse the physical switch between compute nodes, it won't know the real port the mac belong to. And then all the packet to this mac cannot be forward to the right VM.

This patch will prevent arp responder creation for port from vlan network, only create arp responder for tunnel network

networking_vpp/types/type_gpe.py.message: OK, we need to check for other cases of xrange and I'll add a task.

If we're going forward with this, we can't treat VNIs as a non-sparse set (i.e. all VNIs meeting category X are in a set or a list or an iterable) because that leads to huge objects and/or a ton of work, particularly if 'any VNI above 1024' is up for grabs.  We are going to have to keep them as allocation ranges

If we're doing things like set-difference, create something to prune the overlaps - but as far as I can see we have one range allocation from the config and one set from the, so in truth we don't need to do that.  We never require a full list of allocatable VNIs, just one VNI that is allocatable.  we need two operations here:

- is a specific VNI allocatable?  (I don't need the full list for this; it needs to be not in the DB)
- give me one allocatable VNI suitable for a tenant network (I just need the first number in a list of ranges that isn't also in a set constructed from the DB)

I think the most efficient we can get to is something that's O(number of ranges * number of allocated VNIs).  We're currently at something that's O(number of free VNIs).

get_vni_ranges() lists candidate tenant networks, so I think you should only be using it if vni is *not* specified.  If it's specified you're allowed to use it if it's not been used - even if it's outside the conventional ranges.

Non-tenant: available if not used
Tenant: find one within the vni ranges that is not used
Functions change to work with an iterable.

[1] gets you [1]
list([1]) also gets you [1]

I think the call is superfluous
*Really* expensive.  for a range 1-10000 you're checking 10000 values.  Better to check range start and end.
This expects a tuple, but verify_gpe_vni says it's sometimes not a tuple.  (Mypy would have helped spot this)
Also really expensive if the VNI ranges are big, but I think we consider that tolerable right now.  It needs addressing at some point.
Runs the query for every VNI being tested.  Do set(allocated_db_vnis()) outside of the loop.

swift/common/db.py.message:
Why 999? I think the only reason we use that in other places is due to SQLITE_MAX_VARIABLE_NUMBER, which doesn't really apply here -- see https://sqlite.org/limits.html#max_variable_number

I haven't done any benchmarking or anything, but I feel like we could go higher, like 10-100k, as long as we get down to only doing one batch per cycle (see below).

correct, no reason this shouldn't be it's own constraint

I did some benchmarking in dev - no significant difference between 1K and 10K ... 100K is harder to test

Wait, so we're still trying to reclaim *all* reclaimable rows every replicator cycle? I feel like it'd be better to do one batch per cycle and write down `end_marker` somewhere (might be able to squeeze it into a sync table if we want to avoid a migration?) to use as `marker` for the next cycle.

correct, KISS.

there's good reasons to do it all everytime - keep the OTP as small as possible, minimize transfer for reclaimable tombstone rows (i.e. smaller rsyncs)

I don't want to amortize the reclaim further unless testing proves we have too.

An explicit

 # Give container-server a chance to try to keep up with clients
 sleep(1)

after this might not be *so* bad...
Should we move this down just before the continue and piggy-back off that final commit()?

This could almost definitely be bigger.

I'm open to making it either a constraint/constant or a tunable - there's definitely a trade off but a conservative default will trend smaller/slower.

Agreed. I feel like the 1M in the follow-on is probably toward the higher end of where we'd want it to be, though. Just a gut feeling.

I'd lean toward a constant in this file -- seems not unlike the pending cap. OTOH, bug 1877665 also came out of this investigation... but with this change coming, how interested are we in trying to optimize that?

Funny, we really don't use this in account/backend.py, do we?

I guess there generally aren't enough containers to make the batching we do for containers worth it.

while not finished:
    with self.get() as conn:
        marker = self._reclaim(...)
        if not marker:
            finished = True
            self._reclaim_other_stuff(...)
        conn.commit()

? *shrug* w/e
nit: Maybe add a space, so we aren't as dependent on the formatting of clean_batch_qry.
I think you talked about flipping this around, I think that'll be better
this reads pretty ok to me!

idk about that -- but at any rate, it can't be *that many* rows to delete.

Note that this is the *only* delete that triggers if you have <10k tombstone rows in the DB.

hooks/percona_hooks.py.message:
str escapes \n, which becomes \\n and does not get stripped. Shouldn't "pwgen -Cns1 16" be run to make sure no special chars are used, and decoded by using 'us-ascii' encoding?
subprocess.check_output(['pwgen', '-Cns1', '16']).decode('us-ascii').strip()

In py2, it works fine. In py3, it returns ie. "b'Us0L7ROj0poUAXOe\\n'". OTOH, decode('us-ascii') to convert from bytes to str only works on py3.

Maybe six.PY3 boolean would need to be used to get a str?

python2 vs python3 gives different results here:

Python 2.7.15rc1 (default, Apr 15 2018, 21:51:34) 
[GCC 7.3.0] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import subprocess
>>> username = subprocess.check_output(['pwgen', '-s', '16', '1']).strip().decode('us-ascii')
>>> username
u'bgkoJ81gQCbgjaAl'

Python 3.6.6 (default, Sep 12 2018, 18:26:19) 
[GCC 8.0.1 20180414 (experimental) [trunk revision 259383]] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import subprocess
>>> username = subprocess.check_output(['pwgen', '-s', '16', '1']).strip().decode('us-ascii')
>>> username
'DNgznXjtCD4QSg5c'

More generally, I'd expect something like:

username = username = subprocess.check_output(['pwgen', '-s', '16', '1']).strip()
if six.PY3"
  username = username.decode('us-ascii')

This has the side effect of continually mutating the username presented back to the consuming service - that's why the remote_unit name is split in / to just get to the service name sans the unit number.

Juju relations are 1 -> N broadcast on relation-set - all remote units will see the user key change every time a new unit joins the same relation instance.

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message: Nice refactor! As _create_guest_from_domain() cannot return None (I trust mypy here) therefore this is logically equivalent with the base code.
This isn't the same thing. The previous check wouldn only pass if the virt type was != lxc and we weren't doing a live snapshot
This also isn't the same: there can be more states than PAUSED and RUNNING, though I'm not sure if we will see any of those here. Maybe shutdown?

Yes, exactly. It took me a bit to grok due to terrible naming, but this function is the reverse of '_prepare_domain_for_snapshot' above. As you can see, that only suspends the instance if we are in the PAUSED or RUNNING state, so we should only resume the instance (which is what the to '_create_guest_from_domain' is effectively doing - see below) if the instance was in any of those states.
So you mean there are potential cases when the old code did not call _create_domain at all?

This is actually a garbage function. The Guest object maintains no state outside of the '_domain' attribute, so in the below case, guest_a and guest_b are essentially identical:

  guest_a = libvirt_guest.Guest(domain)
  guest_b = libvirt_guest.Guest(domain)

So all this is *actually* doing is calling 'guest.launch(pause=pause)', which we should instead do in the caller.
I actually though about doing this, but preferred the symmetry of variable names in _suspend_guest_for_snapshot/_resume_guest_after_snapshot. Now that there's another voice in favor, I can change
ima say this used to be longer but got chopped down through subsequent changes. What you've said makes sense
nit - current_power_state otherwise it's slightly confusing given we are passing in the original state above.
I was about to write this as a comment given the PCI stuff below, the TODO is enough for now but we should definitely call self.resume in the future.
supernit - Would be cool if we could just pass a target power_state here instead of having two separate booleans.
Okay, this necessitates reworking '_create_guest_with_network' and its many callers, which is too much work for now. I'm going to leave this for now :)
Agreed. I'll see how easy it is to do
Turns out these are actually ints. mypy can't tell yet because nova.compute.power_state isn't yet type checked /o\

doc/source/configuration/intel_n3000_fpg.message: Can we put the 'system host-unlock <worker>' on the line below?

Perhaps we should add a section about configuring the XL710 network interfaces for SR-IOV?  They would follow the exact same configuration procedure as other SR-IOV network interfaces, but it might be useful to note that the NICs on the N3000 can be identified by their device id via the system host-port-list <worker> command.  For example:

+--------------------------------------+------------+----------+--------------+--------+-----------+-------------+------------------------------------------------+
| uuid                                 | name       | type     | pci address  | device | processor | accelerated | device type                                    |

Systemd determines when a service should start by use of the 'After=' and 'Before=' values found in the '[Unit]' section of the 'service' file.  These values take a space separated list of other services or 'targets'.  A 'target' is effectively a collection of services.  e.g. the log management service has ...

[Unit]
Description=StarlingX Log Management
After=network.target syslog-ng.service iscsid.service sw-patch.service
Before=config.service pmon.service

So it can't start until we have patched software, a network, a disk and the syslog-ng service all up and running.

I was careless in the original patch and did the fix based on just logs (SRIOV hardware was hard to get, maybe a bit easier now). Then due to an error in our internal bugzilla (my error, full mea culpa here), our QE didn't look at it, and it went straight to release.

*This* patch I have actually tested, and made sure the internal bugzilla fields are set correctly to ensure QE coverage.

However as Sean is about to comment (or has already commented), turns out this patch is incomplete, and only works for networking driver-bound PFs (which was the case in the env I had when testing this). It's still better than nothing, but doesn't cover all the cases, so the plan is to convert it to a Partial-bug, and then hunt for SRIOV hardware to develop a complete fix.

So we in the VFIO-PCI case we can't get a MAC for the device. So that means if we're going to expose it in the device metadata we need 2 things:

1. Expose something *other* than the tag, as the tag alone is useless. This can be the <target> PCI address, see comment on L9461.

2. Find a way to associate a device tag to a device in the instance XML. Currently that's done with MAC addresses, but it's probably possible to do it with PCI addresses as well, however that'll most likely involve some sort of database migration, as currently the only place we store NIC tags is in VirtualInterface objects, and the only other piece of information that's stored there is the MAC address.

This is wrong, should be the address from <target>, not <source>, but the latter is all that LibvirtConfigGuestHostdevPCI currently supports.

This isn't strictly speaking the same bug, so follow-up patch?

So, in order to get the flag set before the leapp upgrade you would need to add:

upgrade_tasks:
  - name: Set noout flag
    tags:
      - never
      - system_upgrade
      - system_upgrade_prepare
    when:
      - step|int == 3
      - upgrade_leapp_enabled
    command: "{{ container_cli }} exec -u root ceph-mon-${HOSTNAME} ceph osd set noout
    tripleo_delegate_to: "{{ groups['ceph_mon'] | default([]) }}"

I want this to happen when *any* of the overcloud nodes is doing its "openstack overcloud upgrade run --stack STACK NAME --limit NODE NAME"

Basically after LEAPP rebooted the node

this isn't a valid option...the tripleo_delegate_to is a parameter from the tripleo-container-stop ansible role: https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible/src/branch/master/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_container_stop/defaults/main.yml

You will need to use delegate_to.

So, if your intention is to run this before the leapp upgrade, it won't happen with this combination of when/tags...this, as it is right now, would be executed in the step 1 for the overcloud upgrade run step which happens already after we have updated the operating system via leapp.

You would need to add tags: -never, -system_upgrade   and step 3, for example (anything before step 4, which is when leapp upgrade is run: https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/tripleo-packages/tripleo-packages-baremetal-puppet.yaml#L146-L153

 > - system_upgrade_prepare
 > when:

 > ceph osd set noout

command: "{{ container_cli }} exec -u root ceph-mon-${HOSTNAME} ceph osd set {{ item }}"

            - norebalance

no it should not

this is very confusing

normally jobs with -branch in the name are to be run against the ci repos, so we need branch master.

however for the upgrades case the jobs with -branch are so we can have different voting compared to master

remove this as discussed yesterday 
we can't have stein centos8 end of discussion
if it's not supposed to pass now, it should be in experimental pipeline until it starts to pass

the goal is ussuri voting and master non voting.

for master i think its a reasonable request to move it to experimental assuming we definitely make it non voting.

this current series intends to just bring our coverage back - we dropped all the upgrade jobs after train more/less... https://review.opendev.org/#/q/topic:centos8_upgrades_jobs+(status:open+OR+status:merged)

i am following up with bugs and making voting as a new series

sagi upgrades is a special case ... master upgrades is always non voting

by moving to experimental it means we will hardly ever see the job run.

neutron/objects/subnet.py.message:
If query is still returning segment_id=None, this is because, somehow, this network has some subnets without segment associated. In any case, although that could be filtered in the query, you can also remove those None values here:

return [segment_id for (segment_id,) in query.all() if segment_id]
BTW, try to reproduce it with UTs. This is the fastest way to properly test this query, that's why we have all the framework ready for this.

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/.message: How about decrease the priority here?
How about increase the priority here?

Hi Liu, please review https://review.opendev.org/#/c/741444/.

I think you are right, increasing this priority you can solve DVR and non-DVR, leaving the drop flows untouched.

I checked the code history, this could trace back to the multiple provider-networks, yes a very long time ago, about 8 years. It should be related to these bps:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/provider-networks
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/neutron-specs/specs/juno/provider-network-partial-specs.html
https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-manuals/+bug/1226279

This is the original commit:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/11388/11/quantum/plugins/openvswitch/agent/ovs_quantum_agent.py@453

For my understanding of these drops, it is useful for those packets whose destination is not in this host or just broadcast. Neutron does not accept them and will not allow the to flood (NORMAL) to any ports on this ovs bridge. The following is a running cloud output, you may see there are tons of packets dropped by these flows:
# ovs-ofctl dump-flows br-int|grep drop
 cookie=0xfdc9b65a3c57ece4, duration=76264.990s, table=0, n_packets=243569, n_bytes=16509630, idle_age=65534, hard_age=65534, priority=2,in_port=5793 actions=drop
 cookie=0xfdc9b65a3c57ece4, duration=76264.989s, table=0, n_packets=7846375815, n_bytes=710820826710, idle_age=0, hard_age=65534, priority=2,in_port=5794 actions=drop

# ovs-ofctl show br-int|grep addr|grep 5793
 5793(int-br-ex): addr:4e:32:1b:84:c5:af
# ovs-ofctl show br-int|grep addr|grep 5794
 5794(int-br-vlan): addr:b6:91:c2:fe:2f:9e

So, IMO, we should keep these drops. But instead of driectly removing these code, I suggest that you can add a new config option (need to be approved by the team). If your local cloud wants to disable it, do it by setting this. The default behavior should not be changed.

I'm not sure if we should completely drop those rules. It's there for a specific reason.
Maybe we don't need them to be installed in case of dvr, as it will be overwritten quickly but in non-dvr case those rules are still needed IMO.
pep8: E303 too many blank lines (2)
pep8: E501 line too long (80 > 79 characters)

Hi Norman. If those two rules are a duplicate of the rules installed in the DVR setup, that should not affect.

I think the problem you are experiencing is not due to those rules but to the physical bridge cleanup done in L1498. Do you have "drop_flows_on_start" set to False?

Then, during the first polling loop, the agent will call "cleanup_stale_flows" (only once as long as no phy bridge is recreated).

Also remember that during a OVS restart, the local vlan mapping changes.

yes, in case of dvr this shouldn't be installed here becuase dvr_agent's class will similar drop rules in:

 cookie=0x3b1089e77cdd13ca, duration=390.892s, table=2, n_packets=326, n_bytes=18372, idle_age=1, priority=2,in_port=1 actions=drop

And installing that rule here is causing short breakage of the vlan networks in setup with dvr.
yes, this rule is in physical bridge (br-ex in my case)
Your pasted flow here is on physical bridges?
(not related to this patch directly). This comment is not valid anymore IMO. See https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1884254
Once more, please make sure this removal does not introduce some ingress flooding on br-int.
This should be the main reason of the drop after my testing of Line 1592.

Add a sleep(600) here I see the problem, due to the same priority and match rule, the flow on physical bridge was changed from:

'''table=0, n_packets=35024, n_bytes=4019144, priority=2,in_port="phy-br-vlan" actions=goto_table:1'''

to:
'''table=0, n_packets=35031, n_bytes=4019970, priority=2,in_port="phy-br-vlan" actions=drop'''

So how about change the priority of the dvr goto flow with a higher value?

nova/virt/libvirt/host.py.message: What's the use case for this?

This is used in a later patch at [1]. We need the specific UUID so that we know what to lookup when creating the vTPM device [2].

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/631363/49/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py@6553
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/631363/49/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py@5510

I see thanks, this isn't how we handle the secrets with encrypted volumes FWIW. We create the secret while connecting the volume and later lookup the libvirt secret using the volume id while building the libvirt config objects :

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/becca833903e38d8b1c7c983f0c84ebaa13eb62b/nova/virt/libvirt/volume/volume.py#L118-L128

I'm not sure how I feel about using the barbican UUID as the libvirt secret UUID given they are technically different things but I guess it does make debugging failures easier.
These should be kwargs IMHO, I think we can make both default to True in a later change.

Given that nothing else is using these at the moment, I'm tempted to suggest this should be left until we need it. As it stands, I don't think there are any use cases where we wouldn't want these set for vtpm and there are possible implications for other types that we'd need to consider before switching those
ACK that's fine, I might FUP with this later on.
nit - we can replace this entire block if we remove the callers using usage_type='rbd'
True but we can add a constant for that with a simple check. Something for a FUP.
Agreed, though we'd still need a check to make sure the usage_type is one that we support. Can tackle in a follow-up

tripleo_common/actions/ansible.py.message:
Thinking about it again, this won't work when using groups with --limit (with blacklists in the group) unless user explicitly constructs the --limit, which can be a ask from the user pov.

Probably we could have appended which would build that string something like

limit_hosts: Compute
blacklisted_hostnames: ['compute-0', 'compute-11']

--limit 'Compute:!compute-0:!compute11'


Though in scale-down case we would probably like limit_hosts to override blacklisted_hostnames. 

It seems that's what we do in master as we don't use same mistral workflow/action for scale-down.

https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/blob/master/tripleoclient/workflows/deployment.py#L401-L403


This makes the behavior in stable/train different from master (probably we can live with it or try to make it better by passing a different parameter(to the mistral action for scale-down).

>  We shouldn't push blacklists anymore and should better document limit.

IMHO, blacklists are already there and people use it. We can surely deprecate and remove them if we wish.

For scal down we won't merge them. 

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/741406/
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/741407/

No we don't want to merge them because in this instance if a user blacklists a server that is dead but runs the a scale down action, it could end up skipping the host (even if not valid).

We shouldn't push blacklists anymore and should better document limit.
So I just thought through a different case and you may be correct. We might just want to add the merge here.  we'll chat about it in a bit

deployment/openvswitch/openvswitch-dpdk-.message:
We dont need a condition (tso_enable) for boolean parameter. And the parameter should be applied as role-speicif. something like

tripleo_ovs_dpdk_tso: {get_attr: [RoleParametersDpdk, value, enable_tso]}
I was just cautious if we are not allowing "true"/"false" from the user (which are string instead of bool). Is that not  ok ?.
The parameter type is defined as "boolean", so heat will take care of validating other values. Since only 2 possibilities, we dont need a condition, as not setting is is equivalent to false.
